Name: Time-Zone Overlap Load Analyzer
Archetype: Constraint satisfaction and fairness-weighted cost analysis
Purpose: Quantify how current collaboration patterns (meetings and required sync touchpoints) consume overlapping time-zone windows across locations, and measure imbalance of inconvenience and load across team members and sites.
Deliverables: A set of numeric and categorical representations: (1) time-window utilization matrices (rows = time zones or locations, columns = local-hour buckets, values = total scheduled sync minutes); (2) per-person and per-location inconvenience scores (e.g., proportion of sync time outside local core hours); (3) fairness metrics (variance and max-min gaps in inconvenience and sync load); (4) a constraint set describing feasible overlap windows by region without yet proposing new schedules.
Strengths: Precise quantification of when and where synchronous collaboration pressure occurs; detection of systematically overburdened time zones or roles; ability to express the current setup as a constraint satisfaction problem (who can meet with whom, when) and to expose constraint tightness and bottlenecks; supports later optimization of meeting load by providing a rigorous baseline of overlap costs.
Watch-out: Failure_Mode: Breaks when time-zone data, working hours, or meeting schedules are missing, inconsistent, or only qualitatively described; produces misleading results if core hours or flexibility constraints are not explicitly modeled; cannot judge the importance or quality of meetings, only their temporal and fairness impact. Topics to avoid: Do not recommend specific schedule changes; do not design meeting agendas; do not assess communication effectiveness or emotional fatigue; do not compare tools; restrict reasoning to temporal load, overlap feasibility, and fairness metrics.
